intro: Evolvulus arbuscula subsp. canus, commonly known as the white-leaf morning glory, is a flowering plant native to Central America and parts of South America. It is a herbaceous annual that typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, with slender, hairy stems and alternate leaves. The leaves are ovate to lanceolate, often with a pale green or nearly white coloration, giving the plant its common name. Its flowers are trumpet-shaped, usually pale blue or white, and bloom in the morning, hence the name "morning glory." The plant produces small, round berries that contain seeds, which are dispersed by wind or animals.
